text:
Hey Head Squeezers, hope you're well. Andrew
Chamberlain has got in touch on our Facebook

page to ask 'Why does our voice sound different
when recorded?'

This is a great one this is. I thought that
I had a very Barry White style Docotr Lurrrvvveee

kinda voice until I watched some of these
videos and clearly I don't, do I? Please give

us a thumbs up if you have cringed at the
sound of your own voice on a recording.

Now I've touched on the basics of sound before
so I'm not gonna go in to the super simple

stuff.
When you hear that recording of your voice,

say it's played out of a speaker over there,
that sound travels as a series of vibrations

through the air, goes into your ear and vibrates
your ear drum.

If I just take my ear off, put that there,
your vibrating ear drum sets three little

bones vibrating.
The malleus, incus and the stapes, the hammer,

the anvil and the stirrup, they then send
the vibrations in to a spiral structure full

of fluid with little hairs around the edge
called the cochlea.

That transfers those vibrations into nerve
signals that are then sent up to the brain,

and your brain perceives that as those sounds.
So why, when you hear a recording of your

voice, does it sound completely different
to what you think your voice sounds like?

Well that's exactly it because you can hear
your voice in two different ways. The first

is by sending the air vibrating and then that
travels and propagates into your ear drum

but the second way is your vocal chords vibrating
actually sets of vibrations in your skull

and those vibrations travel through your skull
and set your ear drum vibrating.

But as those vibrations travel through the
bone they spread out, the notes actually lower,

the frequency actually drop, that means when
you hear that way you hear a lower voice.

So when you hear the recording you think that's
a lot higher than what I hear in my head.

Unfortunately the reality is that what you
hear on a recording is actually what you sound

like. So you might not sound like a chipmunk
but you definitely sound higher pitched, I

suppose it is something w just have to deal
with. Innit. I think that one answers that

one. If you got anymore questions sound related
or head related do get in touch as normal

twitter, facebook or in the comments below.
And also if you enjoyed this video and your

new to my strand or the head squeeze channel
give us a sub and you'll get a whole lot more

of this stuff in your feed. Until next time
happy head squeezing.
